title: Economics
subtitle: From Scarcity to Value: The Economic Principles of Bitcoin
introduction: Economics studies the allocation of scarce resources. Bitcoin creates absolute scarcity through algorithms, challenging many assumptions of traditional economics. From Austrian School monetary theory to modern macroeconomics, Bitcoin provides a real-world laboratory for economic theory. It's not just a monetary phenomenon, but a rethinking of value, incentives, and economic coordination mechanisms.

sections.title: Monetary Theory: The Nature of Value

content.subtitle: Functions of Money
points: Medium of Exchange: Solving the double coincidence of wants
Store of Value: Preserving purchasing power over time
Unit of Account: Unified standard for measuring value
Deferred Payment: Basis for debt and contract pricing

content.subtitle: Evolution of Money
points: Commodity Money: Physical items like shells, cattle, salt
Metallic Money: Natural scarcity of gold and silver
Fiat Currency: Government-backed paper money
Digital Currency: Algorithm-guaranteed digital scarcity

sections.title: Economics of Scarcity: Supply and Demand

content.subtitle: Bitcoin's Supply Mechanism
points: Fixed Supply: 21 million coin cap
Halving Cycles: New supply halves every 4 years
Stock-to-Flow: Gradually approaching gold
Non-Inflationary: Cannot change supply through policy

content.subtitle: Demand Drivers
points: Store of Value Demand: Hedge against inflation and currency devaluation
Transaction Demand: Cross-border payments and unbanked services
Speculative Demand: Opportunities from price volatility
Institutional Demand: Corporate and national reserves

content.subtitle: Fiat Currency Inflation Model
points: Money Supply Growth: Central bank quantitative easing
Inflation Targets: 2% "healthy" inflation rate
Wealth Redistribution: From savers to borrowers
Keynesian Approach: Stimulating consumption and investment

content.subtitle: Bitcoin's Deflationary Model
points: Decreasing Supply: Mining rewards continuously halving
Purchasing Power Growth: Long-term appreciation expectation
Savings Incentive: Reward for delayed consumption
Austrian School: Natural market adjustment

content.subtitle: Comparison with Gold
points: Scarcity: Bitcoin is more predictable
Divisibility: Bitcoin divisible to 8 decimal places
Portability: Bitcoin easier for cross-border transfer
Verifiability: Bitcoin authenticity easier to verify

content.subtitle: Store of Value Characteristics
points: Durability: Cannot rot or be damaged
Scarcity: Limited and predictable supply
Acceptability: Widely recognized and accepted
Liquidity: Easy to buy, sell, and convert

content.subtitle: Exchange Ecosystem
points: Centralized Exchanges: High liquidity but requires trust
Decentralized Exchanges: Trustless but lower liquidity
Over-the-Counter (OTC): Large trades avoiding slippage
Futures and Derivatives: Leverage and hedging tools

content.subtitle: Price Formation Mechanism
points: Supply-Demand Equilibrium: Buyer-seller dynamics
Arbitrage Mechanism: Price convergence across markets
Market Depth: Order book thickness
Volatility: Characteristic of emerging markets

content.subtitle: Monetary Policy Challenges
points: Weakened Central Bank Control: Cannot regulate Bitcoin supply
Free Capital Flow: Breaking through capital controls
Currency Competition: Fiat monopoly broken
Policy Transmission Blocked: Traditional tools ineffective

content.subtitle: Financial System Transformation
points: Disintermediation: Direct peer-to-peer transactions
Financial Inclusion: Opportunities for the unbanked
Systemic Risk: New financial stability challenges
Regulatory Dilemma: Cross-border nature and anonymity

keyInsights: Scarcity is an important source of value, but not the only one
Centralized control of monetary policy is both an advantage and a risk
Deflationary economics may change consumption and investment behavior
Digital scarcity has created a new economic paradigm
